body.head:
Coroner's Inquest Transcript The following is the transcript of the shorthand notes taken at the Coroner's inquest held on the body of William Desmond Taylor at Ivy H. Overholtzer [Mortuary] at Los Angeles, California on the 4th day of February, 1922 at 10:00 a.m.
Henry Peavey, being first duly sworn, testified as follows:

sp.speaker: NANCE:
sp.ab: Please state your name.

sp.speaker: PEAVEY:
sp.ab: Henry Peavey.

sp.speaker: NANCE:
sp.ab: Where do you live?

sp.speaker: PEAVEY:
sp.ab: I live at 127 1/2 East 3rd Street.

sp.speaker: NANCE:
sp.ab: What is your occupation?

sp.speaker: PEAVEY:
sp.ab: Cook and valet.

sp.speaker: NANCE:
sp.ab: Mr. Peavey, were you employed by Mr. Taylor, the deceased in this case?

sp.speaker: PEAVEY:
sp.ab: Sir?

sp.speaker: NANCE:
sp.ab: Were you employed by the dead man in the case?

sp.speaker: PEAVEY:
sp.ab: Yes,sir.

sp.speaker: NANCE:
sp.ab: How long have you been working for him?

sp.speaker: PEAVEY:
sp.ab: About six months.

sp.speaker: NANCE:
sp.ab: Were you in the house on the evening when he was found dead there?

sp.speaker: PEAVEY:
sp.ab: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: NANCE:
sp.ab: What time did you leave the house?

sp.speaker: PEAVEY:
sp.ab: I figured it was about a quarter past [seven] that I left the house.

sp.speaker: NANCE:
sp.ab: Where was he when you left?

sp.speaker: PEAVEY:
sp.ab: He was sitting in a chair facing ust to the [illegible] now, and Miss Normand was sitting in a chair just the same. They were discussing a red-backed book.

sp.speaker: NANCE:
sp.ab: In what part of the house were they?

sp.speaker: PEAVEY:
sp.ab: They were near the dining-room, where you enter the dining-room from the living-room.

sp.speaker: NANCE:
sp.ab: That is a two-story apartment, is it not?

sp.speaker: PEAVEY:
sp.ab: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: NANCE:
sp.ab: And on the ground floor, how many rooms?

sp.speaker: PEAVEY:
sp.ab: The living-room, dining-room and kitchen.

sp.speaker: NANCE:
sp.ab: Now, the entrance to this apartment is immediately into the front there, is it not-the front room, rather?

sp.speaker: PEAVEY:
sp.ab: The front room, yes sir.

sp.speaker: NANCE:
sp.ab: They were seated?

sp.speaker: PEAVEY:
sp.ab: Near the dining-room there, in the living-room, near the entrance to the dining-room.

sp.speaker: NANCE:
sp.ab: When you went out, which way did you go out, at the front or the back?

sp.speaker: PEAVEY:
sp.ab: I went out the front way. I always lock up the back door when I go out. I always lock the back door screen; it has a hook on the inside. I used the front door to come out all the time.

sp.speaker: NANCE:
sp.ab: Did you carry the back door key with you?

sp.speaker: PEAVEY:
sp.ab: No, sir. I always turn it in the door and leave it just as it is.

sp.speaker: NANCE:
sp.ab: Now, when did you next see Mr. Taylor?

sp.speaker: PEAVEY:
sp.ab: The next morning, when I went to work.

sp.speaker: NANCE:
sp.ab: What time are you in the habit of coming to work?

sp.speaker: PEAVEY:
sp.ab: I am usually there about half past seven.

sp.speaker: NANCE:
sp.ab: What time did you arrive there the next morning?

sp.speaker: PEAVEY:
sp.ab: just about half past seven.

sp.speaker: NANCE:
sp.ab: What day was that?

sp.speaker: PEAVEY:
sp.ab: Thursday morning [February 2].

sp.speaker: NANCE:
sp.ab: On arriving there, what did you do?

sp.speaker: PEAVEY:
sp.ab: I picked up the paper first; I stopped in a drug store at the corner of 5th and Los Angeles to get a bottle of medicine - milk of magnesia, he usually takes that every morning; I bought that on my way out. I picked up the paper and unlocked the door. The first thing I saw was his feet. I looked at his feet a few minutes and said, "Mr. Taylor." He never moved. I stepped a little further in the door, and seen his face, and turned and ran out and hollered.

sp.speaker: NANCE:
sp.ab: Who did you summon? Who did you call to?

sp.speaker: PEAVEY:
sp.ab: I don't know.

sp.speaker: NANCE:
sp.ab: You just made a lot of noise to attract all the attention you could?

sp.speaker: PEAVEY:
sp.ab: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: NANCE:
sp.ab: Several people came, did they?

sp.speaker: PEAVEY:
sp.ab: Yes, sir. I think Mr. Desmond [sic], and the gentleman who owns the court was the first.

sp.speaker: NANCE:
sp.ab: You mean Mr. Jessurun?

sp.speaker: PEAVEY:
sp.ab: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: NANCE:
sp.ab: Who else came?

sp.speaker: PEAVEY:
sp.ab: And Mr. - you see, I don't know their names - I just seen them - the two gentlemens next door, Mr. MacLean and Mr. - I can't think of the other gentleman's name - right next door to us [Charles Maigne].
